trial_identification.studytitle: Pain during second eye cataract surgery under topical anesthesia: an intraindividual study
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Pain during second eye cataract surgery under topical anesthesia: an intraindividual study

interventions.interventions: Patients will be asked to grade pain experienced during both first and second eye cataract surgery under topical anesthesia, using a Visual Analog Scale. Difference in pain perception during first and second eye surgery will then be evaluated. Partecipants will be recruited over a period of 3 years, in order to reach a sample size of 60 patients for statistical evaluation. Allowing for possible drop-outs due to intraoperative events causing differences in surgical technique, at least 70 elegible patients will be recruited for the study

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary Outcome: Visual Analog Scale pain score after cataract procedure
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Immediately after both first and second eye surgery. Time between first and second eye surgery may vary considerably, depending upon cataract evolution in each individual patient.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary Outcome: subjective evaluation of difference in pain perception between first and second eye procedure. Patients will be asked at the end of surgery on the second eye if they had more pain during the first or the second procedure.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients undergoing bilateral non-simultaneous cataract surgery
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: secondary cataracts ineligible for topical anesthesia unilateral cataract

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Aim of the study was to investigate 1) if second eye cataract surgery under topical anesthesia is more painful than surgery on the first eye; 2) if pain experienced during the procedure on the first eye may predict the pain of the second procedure; 3) if patients' cooperation is different between the first and the second eye procedure.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Comitato Etico Ospedale San Pietro - Fatebenefratelli
